00032 //
00033 
00034 // This should be defined, however it isnt on solaris 5.8
00035 #ifndef NAN
00036 // if NAN is not defined then dont use the "nan()" function
00037 // as it is not likely to be defined either.
00038 // passing NULL to nan on redhat-8 causes a SEGV
00039 // #define NAN nan(NULL)
00040 // Instead we generate our own NAN value.
00041 #ifdef _WIN32 
00042   #include <limits>
00043   #define NAN numeric_limits<double>::quiet_NaN()
00044 #else
00045  #define NAN (0.0/0.0)
00046 #endif
00047 #endif

00068 /*! Max n for which we can compute psignrank() */

00071 /*! Max n for which we can compute pwilcox() */
00072 #define PWILCOX_MAX_N 1000

00074 /*! For n exceeding this the normal approximation to the signed rank test will be used. */
00075 #define APPROX_SIGNRANK_CUTOFF 50   
00076 
00077 /*! For sample size exceeding this the normal approximation will be used for signed rank tests */
00078 #define APPROX_RANKSUM_CUTOFF 50

00080 /*! Tail types for statistical tests. */
00081 typedef enum _TAIL_TYPE {
00082         /*! One sided lower tail */
00083         ONE_SIDED_LOWER,
00084 
00085         /*! Once sided upper tail */
00086         ONE_SIDED_UPPER,
00087 
00088         /*! Two sided tail */
00089         TWO_SIDED
00090 } TAIL_TYPE;

00196 /*! Performs a Wilcoxon rank sum test.  This is the simplest interface.
00197  *
00198  * @param x1 The array of values for the first sample.
00199  * @param n1 The number of points in the x1 array.
00200  * @param x2 The array of values for the second sample.
00201  * @param n2 The number of points in the x2 array.
00202  * @param tail_type The tail type for the test (one of ONE_SIDED_UPPER, ONE_SIDED_LOWER, TWO_SIDED)
00203  * @param log_p Boolean flag indicating if the p-value should be logged.
00204  * @return The computed p-value.
00205  */
00206 double ranksumTest(double *x1, int n1, double *x2, int n2, int tail_type, bool log_p);
00207 
00208 
00209 /*! Performs a Wilcoxon rank sum test.  This is the full interface.
00210  *
00211  * @param x1 The array of values for the first sample.
00212  * @param n1 The number of points in the x1 array.
00213  * @param x2 The array of values for the second sample.
00214  * @param n2 The number of points in the x2 array.
00215  * @param tied Boolean flag, value will reflect whether or not there were ties in the input data.
00216  * @param pval The computed p-value.
00217  * @param tail_type The tail type for the test (one of ONE_SIDED_UPPER, ONE_SIDED_LOWER, TWO_SIDED)
00218  * @param log_p Boolean flag indicating if the p-value should be logged.
00219  */
00220 void ranksumTest(double *x1, int n1, double *x2, int n2, bool *tied, double *pval, int tail_type, bool log_p);
00221 
00222 
00223 /*! Performs a Wilcoxon rank sum test.  This is the legacy interface.
00224  *
00225  * @param x1 The array of values for the first sample.
00226  * @param n1 The number of points in the x1 array.
00227  * @param x2 The array of values for the second sample.
00228  * @param n2 The number of points in the x2 array.
00229  * @param nTied Value will be incremented by one if there were ties in the input data.
00230  * @param pval The computed p-value.
00231  * @param signal The median of all pairwise differences in x1 and x2 (Hodges-Lehmann estimator)
00232  * @param tail_type The tail type for the test (one of ONE_SIDED_UPPER, ONE_SIDED_LOWER, TWO_SIDED)
00233  */
00234 void ranksumTest(double *x1, int n1, double *x2, int n2, int *nTied, double *pval, double *signal, int tail_type);
00235 
00236 
00237 /*! Performs a Wilcoxon signed rank test.  This is the simplest interface.
00238  *
00239  * @param x The array of values to analyze.
00240  * @param n The number of points in the x array.
00241  * @param tail_type The tail type for the test (one of ONE_SIDED_UPPER, ONE_SIDED_LOWER, TWO_SIDED)
00242  * @param log_p Flag indicating if the p-value should be logged.
00243  * @return The computed p-value.
00244  */
00245 double signedRankTest(double *x, int n, int tail_type, bool log_p);
00246 
00247 /*! Performs a signed rank test.  This is the full interface.
00248  *
00249  * @param x The array of values to analyze.
00250  * @param n The number of points in the x array.
00251  * @param tied The number of observations that were tied.
00252  * @param nZero The number of observations that were zero.
00253  * @param tiedAndZero The number of observations that were tied and zero.
00254  * @param pval The p-value.
00255  * @param signal The pseudo median.
00256  * @param tail_type The tail type for the test (one of ONE_SIDED_UPPER, ONE_SIDED_LOWER, TWO_SIDED)
00257  * @param log_p Flag indicating if the p-value should be logged.
00258  */
00259 void signedRankTest(double *x, int n, bool *tied, bool *nZero, bool *tiedAndZero, double *pval, int tail_type, bool log_p);
00260 
00261 /*! Performs a signed rank test, returns logged lower-tail p-value and computes pseudoMedian.  This is the legacy interface.
00262  *
00263  * @param x The array of values to analyze.
00264  * @param n The number of points in the x array.
00265  * @param tied The number of observations that were tied.
00266  * @param nZero The number of observations that were zero.
00267  * @param tiedAndZero The number of observations that were tied and zero.
00268  * @param pval The p-value.
00269  * @param signal The pseudo median.
00270  */
00271 void signedRankTest(double *x, int n, int *tied, int *nZero, int *tiedAndZero, double *pval, double *signal);
00272 
00273 /*! Computes the pseudo median.
00274  *
00275  * @param x The array of values for which to compute the pseudomedian.
00276  * @param n The number of points in the x array.
00277  * @return The pseudo median.
00278  */
00279 double pseudoMedian(double *x, int n);
00280 
00281 /*! Computes the median over all pairwise differences in two arrays of values.
00282  *
00283  * @param x  The first array of values.
00284  * @param nX The number of points in the x1 array.
00285  * @param y  The second array of values.
00286  * @param nY The number of points in the x2 array.
00287  * @return The median of all n1*n2 pairwise differences.
00288  */
00289 double medianDifference(double *x, int nX, double *y, int nY);
00290 
00291 /*! This function calculates Pearson's correlation coefficient between 2 arrays of floats
00292  *
00293  * @param x1 The first array of floats
00294  * @param x2 The second array of floats
00295  * @param nPoints The size of each array. assumed the same
00296  * @param transform A function to transform the data
00297  * @return Pearson's correlation
00298  */
00299 double PearsonCorrelation(float *x1, float *x2, int nPoints, float(*transform)(float x) = NULL);
